Start with the definition people use in chemistry: an element is a substance made of only one kind of atom — atoms that all have the same number of protons in their nucleus. - Gold atoms all have 79 protons, so gold is element number 79 on the periodic table (symbol Au).  
- Samples of native gold found in nature are the metal in elemental form (not a compound).  
- You cannot chemically break gold down into simpler substances; you can make gold ions or gold compounds (for example Au3+ salts), but those species are still made from gold atoms. To change gold into a different element you would need a nuclear reaction that changes the proton count.  
- Analytical methods (mass spectrometry, X‑ray fluorescence, atomic spectroscopy) identify gold by its unique atomic number and spectral lines, confirming it is a single chemical element.

Common source of confusion
- Jewelry and coins are often alloys (mixtures) of gold with other metals, so a ring may not be "pure gold." That doesn’t change the fact that the pure metal itself is a chemical element.

A simple illustration you can describe or perform
- Dissolve a small gold item (or a speck of native gold) in aqua regia to produce gold ions in solution, then reduce the ions back to metallic gold: you still have gold throughout — you’ve only changed its chemical state, not turned it into another element.
